author: greenkeeperio-bot
description:
Hello lovely humans, [codemirror](https://www.npmjs.com/package/codemirror) just published its new version 5.25.0.
State Update :rocket:
Dependency codemirror
New version 5.25.0
Type dependency
This version is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of codemirror. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn’t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- The new version differs by 469 commits . - [`727b10a`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/727b10ab632bdd4eaa41a6ca3766a5c50b5562da) Mark version 5.25.0 - [`f2d6eee`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/f2d6eeeb94734429d0d82b05e7ffdece49736bd6) [fold demo] Use htmlmixed mode in HTML folding demo - [`0b00c0e`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/0b00c0e12fe919865929053e03b2c9dccda0779c) Add role=presentation to more elements to help screenreaders - [`f583ab9`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/f583ab93d0e6f5f55eedbb9bd3c99e26a0270887) [continuelist addon] Continue task lists - [`6b59a2c`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/6b59a2c832fc3aec5e730da973081c822d1f3dfa) [real-world uses] Add some links - [`c96aae3`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/c96aae3d946b3f8f78167e3ec8f22976f426a9ce) [soy mode] Fix indentation and restore previous local states - [`2f43bcc`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/2f43bccc955c06016aca79e7523a3f84e8f5d9f8) [javascript mode] Recognize TypeScript class fields without type - [`66c68db`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/66c68db0c4fcbc6bb6ce735c2def8f03c3f43478) [comment addon] When uncommenting a block comment, make sure its a single one - [`27bfaba`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/27bfabac6e7f39088092b9ce9a692bdb382d3b1b) Also hide selection in gutter on Firefox - [`1d00df9`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/1d00df9e9e6ced8516a3400e3f4bdb8147ab514d) Make backspace across lines work in Chrome Android - [`cfcad60`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/cfcad600a6b2713347c64d2f434a6e78ffeb4e8f) Fix bug in reading contenteditable text from DOM - [`aab2357`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/aab23579713141613399605e3bb6a4a25a1c13dd) [css mode] Add system-ui as value keyword - [`7580a1d`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/7580a1dc1d7ce1ab929a0be7cd3875d976fcf056) [markdown mode] Simplify leaving fenced block - [`c88b02c`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/c88b02c5badc415abb25ef83ed28e22a8f94f940) Always check whether to scroll window on .scrollIntoView - [`facc9c8`](https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/commit/facc9c869f1799d8c25ec0fd76995c5ed8f9d675) [linter] Allow tabs in lib/codemirror.css There are 250 commits in total. #### Pre-Submission Checklist - [x] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp. - [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`) - [x] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit). - [x] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes. #### Type of Change - [x] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality) - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality) - [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations) #### Checklist: - [x] Tested changes locally. - [x] Closes currently open issue: Closes #14116 #### Description http://beta.freecodecamp.com/challenges/basic-css/change-the-color-of-text challenge does not allow for spaces around `style` and its value: `

CatPhotoApp

` should be a valid answer according to https://www.w3.org/TR/html51/syntax.html#elements-attributes under (see **Double-quoted attribute value syntax**). This PR simply adds `\s*` around the `=` sign in the assertion regexp. Thanks!

author: greenkeeperio-bot
description:
Hello lovely humans, [redux-form](https://www.npmjs.com/package/redux-form) just published its new version 6.6.1.
State Update :rocket:
Dependency redux-form
New version 6.6.1
Type dependency
This version is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of redux-form. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn’t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/releases/tag/v6.6.1)

Bug Fixes

  • Fixed propTypes for warn and validate. 08a377e
  • Fixed bug with syncErrors when using redux-form/immutable. #2755
  • Fixed some propTypes for diehard forbidExtraProps people. #2738 #2707 #2744
  • Removed submit promise on STOP_SUBMIT. #2731 #2591

Features

  • Added additional dispatch and props parameters to form-wide onChange. #2748 #2728
--- The new version differs by 840 commits . - [`2a86b09`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/2a86b097fe35faa0bbaefec53a5db0d438610ae0) v6.6.1 - [`7c0ae04`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/7c0ae046535c5ec8da39eb394f2654ea444e8dcf) styling fixes on react-widgets example - [`162cf46`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/162cf46f8fc30e6df8f9d6d6a6c29bacc8ffd32f) Fix #2591: stopSubmit removes pending promise from reduxForm. (#2731) - [`c427875`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/c4278753c9406abf4981e3b1fedc2b3c84e28cd4) Fix triggerSubmit/clearSubmit propTypes problems (#2738) - [`494f023`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/494f02360521bf1ab5473b91b2e9badf1302342d) Change the form-level onChange to accept the same args as onSubmit (#2748) - [`17af992`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/17af992d9de0cc8fc917d9e545c9f8a335a08f45) Fix: hasError used plain.getIn(syncErrors, key) for Immutable instead of getIn(syncErrors, key) (#2755) - [`3292f65`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/3292f6579a484844b5e32eb98b908de0d999e9bf) Fix 'renderHobbies' was used before it was defined eslint error (#2750) - [`09a24ad`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/09a24ade862e0fffdb2ff632427f4827e57ac305) Updated deps for examples - [`08a377e`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/08a377ead23ab34c3116c8e02782b1c292b5ebec) fixed warn and validate propTypes - [`cb655a4`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/cb655a45228b56e524e161535c967a9483922790) v6.6.0 - [`97e236a`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/97e236ab46b6cc2d7b081918424f64d72d68a6e1) Replaced usages of for...of construct for stupid IE (#2724) - [`892f45b`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/892f45b5325fa7274cb6f8f0e7b3ea617b960c29) Fix #2718 (Incorrect way of accessing syncErrors, syncWarnings in ConnectedField, ConnectedFieldArray, ConnectedFields for redux-form/immutable) (#2721) - [`27211ee`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/27211eec71eba60bb66cbad003ef4621de309a1a) Added meta.form to FieldArray props (#2712) - [`a5fc53b`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/a5fc53baaf5692210cdccdd727d9cd90c4d40ef7) Update propTypes.js (#2707) - [`bd4d1fb`](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/commit/bd4d1fb3731dcb93e42ca787cbbbd23610aa507f) Add missing prop types for Field, FieldArray and Fields components (#2709) There are 250 commits in total. See the [full diff](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/compare/41ee20d5d0755b6c62082ed60f8476c510d7f5bc...2a86b097fe35faa0bbaefec53a5db0d438610ae0). --- | ✨ Try the all new [Greenkeeper GitHub Integration](https://git.io/uptodate) ✨ | | --- | | With [Integrations](https://developer.github.com/early-access/integrations/) **first-class bot support** landed on GitHub and we’ve rewritten Greenkeeper to take full advantage of it. **Simpler setup, fewer pull-requests, faster than ever**.

Hope those two extra tests are still useful to merge. :)

- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Help Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Closes currently open issue: Closes #14537 and #14020

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Challenge description is a bit confusing as it first mentions even-numbered elements then shows how to target odd elements then asks users to use :even selector.
What is also confusing is the fact that `target` elements have numbers in them and they don't match what `:odd` or `:even` selectors would select. So I changed _even-numbered elements_ to _even elements_, which matches jQuery's doc.

Third test was also off so I fixed that too.

# open for discussion
jQuery's official doc tells us we should use the `filter` method for perf reasons. Should it be mentioned in this challenge?

Thanks!

author: JoolsMcFly
description:
…change 'function' to 'selector' in description

<!-- freeCodeCamp Pull Request Template -->

<!-- IMPORTANT Please review https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/CONTRIBUTING.md for detailed contributing guidelines -->
<!-- Help with PRs can be found at https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors -->

#### Type of Change
<!-- What type of change does your code introduce? After creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
- [x] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Help Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
`Target Elements by id Using jQuery` challenge incorrectly references `:even` selector as a `function`.

I've also changed the third test from
```
"assert(code.match(/<button class=\"btn btn-default target\" id=\"target2\">/g), 'message: Only use jQuery to add these classes to the element.');"
```
to
```
"assert(code.match(/\\$\\(\".target:nth-child\\(2\\)\"\\)/g) || code.match(/\\$\\('.target:nth-child\\(2\\)'\\)/g) || code.match(/\\$\\(\".target\"\\).filter\\(\":nth-child\\(2\\)\"\\)/g) || code.match(/\\$\\('.target'\\).filter\\(':nth-child\\(2\\)'\\)/g), 'message: Only use jQuery to add these classes to the element.');"
```

which allows the use if `filter` method.

Thanks!

author: P1xt
description:
@QuincyLarson
@AdventureBear

Here's the bulk load json for the Project Euler stuff. It may or may not need to be resubmitted. I won't be resubmitting it but either of you are free to.

I ran a quick scrape of Project Euler to fill out the bulk of what will be needed for the add-project-euler-problems feature

The json contains all 600 existing questions, including a test against a confirmed correct answer for each question for which a confirmed answer is available. There is still more work to be done, but this should handle the initial bulk load.

- Questions for which I did not have confirmed answers for have "TODO" marked in the tests.
- Some descriptions contain latex - I scraped them off the official project euler site (where they use MathJax)
- Some descriptions contain images - easily found in the json by looking for contiguous blank lines - these will have to be handled manually.

In gulpfile.js I changed the gulp task to run eslint instead of jsonlint. 

Additionally there was some strange lint issue with 2 unknown characters in a Russian translation in some challenge file.

description:

- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Closes currently open issue (replace XXXX with an issue no): Closes #14608 

#### Description
Rewrites the description of the challenge "jQuery: Target the Children of an Element Using jQuery".
It doesn't change the challenge itself other than a slight rewording of the instructions.

The reason for the change is that the description was incorrect. It described descendants as if they were children. It also previously talked about property inheritance which is outside the scope of the challenge. Going outside the scope violates the instruction "Each challenge should teach exactly one concept" from the challenge style guide.

author: bonham000
description: @QuincyLarson @BerkeleyTrue this branch establishes compatibility between the [alpha version of the freeCodeCamp React/Redux Curriculum](https://github.com/bonham000/fcc-react-tests-module) and the core freeCodeCamp app. **Note:** This is a redo of previous PR because of issues with that branch. I've preserved my commit history here as a record of the sequence of changes I made. I've figured out how to reproduce the testing environment we used in the Alpha version of these challenges within the freeCodeCamp app, and this PR successfully demonstrates the implementation of several specific challenges. The challenges I selected as a whole encompass all of the functionality we rely on, so this effectively paves the way for all of the challenges to be migrated over. I'm aware that @BerkeleyTrue has a large, unmerged PR related to the new app layout (and possibly the React challenges as well?). There will possibly be merge conflicts between these two branches, so I'll defer to you guys to decide how to proceed from here. Here, @no-stack-dub-sack and I are ready to go and begin migrating all the challenges over. That will be a pretty tedious process, but I think that is all that is left now (with the exception of QA) after a consensus is reached on how to integrate these changes into the app. We could either, work on this branch until all the challenges are included here, or, merge this support in and then just start making smaller PRs that add in the actual challenges. ### Main Notes: - I provided the React/Redux challenges with a new `challengeType`, `8`, in order to differentiate them from the other challenges. For the most part, they are treated like `js` challenges, but this allows us to throw a new error toast if code transpilation fails and potentially pipe these challenges through a separate transformation process (to provide the `stage-2` preset). I can expand on this later if needed. - The challenges rely on many dependencies in order to work, e.g. React, Redux, React-Redux packages. I provided these packages via imports directly within the app onto the document which runs the tests. The Enzyme methods we utilize are provide in a simliar manner. - I don't know how the unique IDs are generated from the challenges (in the JSON files). I was just changing random characters in the IDs to get the challenges to seed the database. - I also added an `npm restart` script which reseeds the database and restarts the server in one command to make the process of updating challenges a little more streamlined. - The automated tests that Gulp performs should be compatible with many of the React challenges now. However, there were some problems related to enabling class property transforms with Babel and with running certain Enzyme tests which are not yet resolved, however these should only affect a few challenges. I have some more notes, but they are more related to get the tests for the challenges working correctly. If we move forward with migrating these I'd be happy to create an issue to track that process and document the other notes I have. ### Demo: *** #### Pre-Submission Checklist - [x] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp. - [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`) - [ ] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit): commits unsquashed for review. - [x] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes. #### Type of Change - [x] New feature: this branch establishes the functionality to run the React/Redux challenges in the freeCodeCamp app. #### Checklist: - [x] Tested changes locally.

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Help Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [ ] Closes currently open issue (replace XXXX with an issue no): Closes #XXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
@BerkeleyTrue As discussed, this PR addresses the issue originally addressed in #14986 but couples the challenges less closely with the stylesheets by implementing a global `ChallengeInstructions` component so that both the classic and backend challenge descriptions receive the same styles. Moved the less rules over to `challenges.less`, changing the namespacing of the instructions class names to `challenges` rather than `classic`. 

A couple of notes:
- could not get `npm test` to pass because of the `propTypes` objects in `Back-End.jsx` - it looks like since the redux form prop types are spread out into `propTypes`, the final result is not alphabetical. I didn't make any changes here, so I'm guessing the test was only triggered because I edited the file and that this is an issue that was encountered in the past?
- I was getting some weird behavior with the `challenges-instructions` styles. Everything seems to work correctly (verified in `main.css` that all the rules look correct), but when making and saving changes in JS files, occasionally it would seem as if the styles weren't applied, then I'd make another change and they'd be back. So not sure what's up with that, but I believe the rules are correct. 

Let me know if you think everything looks good.

This PR also makes a slight change to the backend challenges component to improve responsiveness at smaller screen resolutions. Previously, w/ `xs={ 12 }`, the result was too wide and content gets cutoff unless you scroll:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18563015/26385167/ac335fd2-400b-11e7-92c3-cb54e03744f3.png)

So just changed it all too `xs={ 6 }`, && `xsOffset={ 3 }`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18563015/26385136/7801511a-400b-11e7-9121-9477972acb09.png)

author: thomask-gh
description:
The wording made think that we had to return the sum of the two numbers
and *then* all the numbers between them (in the form of an array for
instance). In fact we have to return the sum of the two numbers *plus* the
sum of all numbers the between them.

author: raisedadead
description:

- [ ] ~~disable code auto run~~ auto run works perfectly.
- [ ] ~~add code locking~~ not required as tested.
- [x] disable code uri updating

Closes #13727 

I have tested that this is the minimum required, changes that we need to do get away with the least impact to the existing UX.

Some caveats, that are a part of this, unfortunately, is the ability to share a URL that had the code in it, but IMHO it's for good that we considered deprecating that capability anyways.

Please QA and let me know for changes.

- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Closes currently open issue: Helps to close #14833

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
This adds tests cases to es6 challenge Write Higher Order Arrow Functions. There were commented tests that needed to be implemented. I add only the tests which were specified. I don't believe there is a way to check if an element is a const or a var since the inputted code is changed. The `code` object translates const and let into var. This is likely because not all browsers allow const and let. This means a regex can't be used to check if the user is using a const and not a var. I left those tests commented out.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

This turns the old Free Code Camp into freeCodeCamp in production, which should eliminate confusion until we ship staging (where this has already been fixed).

I also changed the destination of the "chat" button in the navbar to "https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/home" so people can browse the chat rooms instead of just going into the main chat room, and made it open in a new tab instead of using sidecar, which we're still using in production.

author: BerkeleyTrue
description:
Add removes account creation using third party oauth.
Linking third party app will create user credential instead of user identity. Users linking their account before would then be able to login using that linked account. 
Previously created accounts will still be able to use third party oauth to login.
If a linked account is associated with another user, it is instead attached to this user,
If a identity is no longer attached to a user, the identity is marked with a `isOrphaned` property with the username of the user. This allows for easy lookup and deletion.
Adds the ability to mark errors as handled so that they are not reported to production trackers.
Adds opbeat

#### Type of Change
<!-- What type of change does your code introduce? After creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->

- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Help Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Closes currently open issue #15672

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

According to [W3C docs](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/obsolete.html#obsolete) and [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/a#Obsolete)  using the `name` attribute on anchor tags is obsolete and `id` should be used instead.

PR changes the [lesson on Internal Links](http://beta.freecodecamp.com/en/challenges/basic-html-and-html5/link-to-internal-sections-of-a-page-with-anchor-elements) to demonstrate creating an internal link to jump to any element by using `a` tag's `href` to reference the target element's` id`.  Removed references to `name` attribute.  Also in general tried to simplify/shorten the lesson as it was longer than other lessons in this section.

Thanks in advance for review and feedback!

Edit - Forgot to mention that this was brought to attention due to an [issue ](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/testable-projects-fcc/issues/143) opened on _testable-projects-fcc_ repo.   In the test suite, there is a test that checks for an `id `of a internal link target element instead of a `name`.   It seemed better to update the lesson than change the test after learning that `a` tag `name ` attribute is obsolete.

author: xnt
description: Closes #13013 fix(challenges): Provide accessible test description and status #### Pre-Submission Checklist - [X] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp. - [X] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`) - [X] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit). - [X] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes. #### Type of Change - [X] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality) - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality) - [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations) #### Checklist: - [X] Tested changes locally. - [x] Closes currently open issue: Closes #13013 #### Description * Use aria-hide on elements that aren't independently relevant for visually impaired or challenged users * Merge test status and text on a single string * Add the string as the aria text / label of the row element * Force the row element to be a tab stop Changes have been tested with Mac's VoiceOver on Chrome and Safari. Changes _should_ work on NVDA and JAWS (don't have a test environment at the moment). npm test / lint runs fine.

Previously the map had white background color and white color, making it
impossible to see the text. I changed the colors to the standard
night-mode color variables. I also deleted a css class that was not
doing anything.

To QA this, you have to be in night mode, however since the night mode toggle button doesn't currently work you might have to do a workaround like adding the following to local storage:

key: fcc-theme
value: "night"

Closes #15702

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Updated Project Euler seeds for problem 22 

This challenge requires fs, or rather I use module.exports, so I can access the text file as an array of strings in javascript, any other idea how to make this challenge work better?

Here's the solution, I can't add it to the json file, due to it's always failing on the test.
```javascript
function sumNames(n) {
    const names = require('./p022_names');
    names.sort();

    var sum = 0;

    for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        let atoi = names[i]
            .split('')
            .map((_, j) => names[i].charCodeAt(j) - 64)
            .reduce((c, n) => c + n, 0);

        sum += (i + 1) * atoi;
    }

    return sum;
}
```

I added to the json file like this
```json
[
	"function sumNames(n) {",
	"    const names = require('./p022_names');",
	"    names.sort();",
	"",
	"    var sum = 0;",
	"",
	"    for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {",
	"        let atoi = names[i]",
	"            .split('')",
	"            .map((_, j) => names[i].charCodeAt(j) - 64)",
	"            .reduce((c, n) => c + n, 0);",
	"",
	"        sum += (i + 1) * atoi;",
	"    }",
	"",
	"    return sum;",
	"}"
]
```

Some CSS tests were changed to regex tests while the CSS tests weren't working on Firefox. Now that the original issue has been fixed (#15775), these changes can be reverted.
This allows more correct answers to pass as a valid solution again.

The changes reverted were originally made in #13389, #13491 and #13709.

Ignore the first camperbot message, it conflicts with the commitizen guidelines.

author: matthew-t-smith
description:
4 instances of an escaped backslash + s ("\\s") that should simply be a whitespace character match ("\s") fixed. Additional backslashes removed from test at end of solution that escaped quotations around the "555-555-5555" number.

I re-verified that the previous solution failed 4 of the tests (2, 3, 11 and 12), but the new solution solves all the tests on the live site.

- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #14912 

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
As defined in the original issue, this PR adds a new challenge to the MongoDB and Mongoose challenges, in the APIs and Microservices section. This was needed because the following challenge asks for a mLab MongoDB URI without explaining what it is and how to obtain it.
With this challenge, the camper has a walkthrough explaining step-by-step how to:
- create an mLab account
- create a free sandbox database
- create a user in said database
- obtain the standard MongoDB URI for connecting to this database

- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)

- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #15876

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
1. Homogenize the error handler for production and development environments.
2. In the error handler we used to consider only errors wrapped with https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/server/utils/create-handled-error.js#L11 but now we also have errors normalized with https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/common/utils/ajax-stream.js#L79 therefore I added the logic to consider both cases.
3. The errorEpic had only a hardcoded error message so I added the logic to display the message from Ajax Error.

author: mpontus
description:
This PR addresses issue #8096 and enables ES6 class solution to pass the test.

#### Pre-Submission Checklist
- [ ] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp.
- [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`)
- [x] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes.

#### Type of Change
- [ ] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue

Closes #8096

#### Description
Three of the tests had to be removed: class solution does not expose methods as public properties, and does permit access to internal attributes. Exercise description has been altered accordingly.

Another problem with classes is global scope. Evaluating the code multiple times results in an error unless the scope is refreshed. Proposed solution involves reloading an iframe. It also makes it possible to use `const` in global scope throughout all exercises.

author: TheWillG
description:
Fixes #15984.

Small bug fix to catch bracket notation when using String method endsWith() is prohibited.  Adding a second regex check is preferred to other methods such as monkey patching a global object.

		'WONDERFUL',
		'WOOD',

		'YET',
		'YOU',
		'YOUNG',
		'YOUR',
		'YOURSELF',
		'YOUTH',
	];
	const isTriangleNumbers = num => {
		const n = (Math.sqrt(1 + 8 * num) - 1) / 2;

		return n == Math.floor(n);
	};

	const alphabeth = Array.apply(null, Array(26)).map((_, i) =>
		String.fromCharCode(65 + i)
	);

	let count = 0;
	for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		let w = words[i].split('');
		let tn = w
			.map(a => alphabeth.indexOf(a) + 1)
			.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);
            
		if (isTriangleNumbers(tn)) count += 1;
	}

	return count;
}
```

Closes #16124

#### Description
The default text of the legend is confusing given the low range of values used. Cal-heatmap expects higher legend values, such as [10, 20, 30, 40], rather than [1, 2, 3]. This change will hopefully make the mouseover text for the legend a little less confusing.

author: bonham000
description: #### Key: - :white_check_mark: **Challenge is migrated and solution has been successfully QA'd in FCC editor.** - :1st_place_medal: **Challenge copy has been QA'd and confirmed, ready to ship.** ### React Challenges: - :white_check_mark: :1st_place_medal: **1:** Create a Simple JSX element - :white_check_mark: :1st_place_medal: **2:** Create a Complex JSX Element - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **3:** Add Comments in JSX - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **4:** Render HTML Elements to the DOM - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **5:** Define an HTML Class in JSX - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **6:** Learn About Self-Closing JSX Tags - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **7:** Create a Stateless Functional Component - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **8:** Create a Component with React - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **9:** Create a Component with Composition - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **10:** Use React to Render Nested Components - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **11:** Compose React Components - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **12:** Render a Class Component to the DOM - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **13:** Write a React Component from Scratch - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **14:** Pass a String to a Functional Component - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **15:** Pass an Array as Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **16:** Use Default Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **17:** Override Default Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **18:** Use PropTypes to Define the Props You Expect - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **19:** Access Props Using this.props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **20:** Using Props with Stateless Functional Components - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **21:** Create a Stateful Component - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **22:** Render State in the UI - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **23:** Render State in the UI Another Way - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **24:** Set State with this.setState - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **25:** Bind 'this' to a Class Method - ~**26:** Bind 'this' with an ES6 Arrow Function~ - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **27:** Use State to Toggle an Element - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **28:** Write a Simple Counter - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **29:** Create a Controlled Input - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **30:** Create a Controlled Form - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **31:** Pass State as Props to Child Components - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **32:** Pass a Callback as Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **33:** Use the Lifecycle Method componentWillMount - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **34:** Use the Lifecycle Method componentDidMount - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **35:** Add Event Listeners - ✅ :1st_place_medal:**36:** Manage Updates with Lifecycle Methods - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **37:** Optimize Re-Renders with shouldComponentUpdate - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **38:** Introducing Inline Styles - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **39:** Add Inline Styles in React - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **40:** Use Advanced JavaScript in React Render Method - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **41:** Render with an If/Else Condition - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **42:** Use && for a More Concise Conditional - ~**43:** Return null to Prevent Rendering~ - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **44:** Use a Ternary Expression for Conditional Rendering - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **45:** Render Conditionally from Props __Note: Pete, refactor with `simulate()`__ - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **46:** Change Inline CSS Conditionally Based on Component State - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **47:** Use Array.map() to Dynamically Render Elements - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **48:** Give Sibling Elements a Unique Key Attribute - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **49:** Use Array.filter() to Dynamically Filter an Array - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **50:** Render React on the Server with renderToString ### Redux Challenges: - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **1:** Create a Redux Store - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **2:** Get the State of the Redux Store - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **3:** Define a Redux Action - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **4:** Define an Action Creator - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **5:** Dispatch an Action Event - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **6:** Handle an Action in the Store - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **7:** Use a Switch Statement to Handle Multiple Actions - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **8:** Use const for Action Types - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **9:** Register a Store Listener - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **10:** Combine Multiple Reducers - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **11:** Send Action Data to the Store - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **12:** Use Middleware to Handle Asynchronous Actions - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **13:** Write a Counter with Redux - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **14:** Never Mutate State - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **15:** Use the Spread Operator on Arrays - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **16:** Remove an Item from an Array - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **17:** Copy an Object with Object.assign - ~**18:** Use the ES6 Spread Operator with Objects~ ### React-Redux Challenges: - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **1:** Getting Started with React Redux - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **2:** Manage State Locally First - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **3:** Extract State Logic to Redux - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **4:** Use Provider to Connect Redux to React - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **5:** Map State to Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **6:** Map Dispatch to Props - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **7:** Connect Redux to React - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **8:** Connect Redux to the Messages App - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **9:** Extract Local State into Redux - ✅ :1st_place_medal: **10:** Moving Forward From Here *** ### Notes * There is no support for `async` tests in the automated test environment (we skip them currently). * These challenges rely on `editor.getOriginalCode()` to provide the original, untranspiled code string. * Transpiled `head` and `tail` code is required in the FCC editor during for some of these challenges but is currently not working. * Preview function is currently not working for these challenges. *** ### Type of Change - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality) - [x] Closes #16115 ### Description Migrate the React-Redux Curriculum from the [prototype module](https://github.com/bonham000/fcc-react-tests-module) into the FCC codebase. ### Checklist - [x] Populate challenge files (title, description, seed code, solution). - [x] Challenge solutions pass tests under automated test suite. - [x] Manually check solutions work in app. - [x] QA challenge & test copy *** ### Motivational Images ![screen shot 2017-12-03 at 8 10 11 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18126719/33535984-0ba89bf6-d866-11e7-8a19-0e3991f27173.png)

Addresses #12755

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

This PR applies changes from following commits:
- https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/commit/78e86f514f90dc3fd392a52fa52feb180a91f3af introduces Help Dialog which is the main purpose of this PR.
- https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/commit/aefcf9c2acf9def066947ce5c55196fab1ab3e00 changes the forum post template, which has been partially applied but may still require a further review
- https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/commit/52edcedb61ab57d9201d4b4bcf865caf80d894de is non-applicable since new release discourages use of links in modal headers.

Changes in this PR may be easier to follow as separate commits:

https://github.com/mpontus/freeCodeCamp/commit/30ca57210e263dcc0a2d031a7dda0c7139530fbe - add new button and new dialog
https://github.com/mpontus/freeCodeCamp/commit/08f7a93effb7ac1168bf1092c3e2dfc7bafb792b - refactor dialogs to reduce duplication of logic
https://github.com/mpontus/freeCodeCamp/commit/8930e1fa993696f17097808d31efc1664e96a4ee - merge Help button (which used to open Gitter Chatroom) with the new Button (which opens the dialog which now includes link to Gitter Chatroom)

Here's the screenshot of the new Dialog:
https://i.imgur.com/z3faX2E.png

#### Pre-Submission Checklist - [x] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp. - [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`) - [x] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit). - [ ] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes. #### Type of Change - [x] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality) - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality) - [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations) #### Checklist: - [x] Tested changes locally. - [ ] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line) Closes #XXXXX #### Description @BerkeleyTrue @QuincyLarson @bonham000 This PR puts some finishing touches on the React and Redux challenges. There were a few formatting issues since @BerkeleyTrue's recent changes which affected some syntax we used, and more importantly, adds back `
` to the React challenge template for the ReactDOM challenges which were broken with the change. @BerkeleyTrue Also, and I'm a bit befuddled by this, but apparently the `code` variable now seems to contain the untranspiled ES6 code? This was clearly not the case a few months ago, but @Ethan-Arrowood's recent work on the ES6 challenges highlighted this for me, because he seemed to be able to get the original code strings without using your `getUserInput =>` syntax... so not quite sure when this happened, but since this seems to work, I replaced all of that syntax with `code` because its much more readable and intuitive. @QuincyLarson A few other finishing touches and fixes, but everything I've touched on seems to work, but I'm sure the challenges could use a once over QA with someone actually completing each challenge. @Ethan-Arrowood QA'd them for copy and formatting, but I don't believe for working challenges, and since we're not testing them automatically, this would be a good last step if you can find a few volunteers to run through all 3 sections. P.S. I couldn't seem to fix this formatting issue with the new async challenge syntax which @BerkeleyTrue just introduced: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18563015/34143351-516ceba6-e45a-11e7-8194-592b154600fc.png)

description:
<!-- freeCodeCamp Pull Request Template -->

<!-- IMPORTANT Please review https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/CONTRIBUTING.md for detailed contributing guidelines -->
<!-- Help with PRs can be found at https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors -->
<!-- Make sure that your PR is not a duplicate -->

#### Pre-Submission Checklist
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick all the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- All points should be verified, otherwise, read the CONTRIBUTING guidelines from above-->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp.
- [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`)
- [x] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes.

#### Type of Change
<!-- What type of change does your code introduce? After creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
- [ ] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
This update brings fuzzy-full-text search to freeCodecamp. The results show highlighted matches, and we now have a custom placeholder.

![animation of the results being shown from the search bar](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18572518/34161166-9ec78d62-e4c7-11e7-879d-9b61439dcd40.gif)

- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #16235 

#### Description
When the import/export challenges were executed, they were looking for a
require method, export method, and specific class structures when
importing modules. I've introduced the ability to create mock
classes/functions. This is tested locally and everything passes.

**Fixes the following challenges:**
[Understand the Differences Between import and require](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/es6/understand-the-differences-between-import-and-require)
[Use export to Reuse a Code Block](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/es6/use-export-to-reuse-a-code-block)
[Use * to Import Everything from a File](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/es6/use--to-import-everything-from-a-file)
[Create an Export Fallback with export default](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/es6/create-an-export-fallback-with-export-default)
[Import a Default Export](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/es6/import-a-default-export)

CC: @Ethan-Arrowood, @BerkeleyTrue, @QuincyLarson

There were two (2) tests that were failing for the React `shouldComponentUpdate` challenge, and the output referenced a regex error. Upon inspection, the test were written correctly but the final argument of the `assert()` method (i.e. the string displayed if the test fails) was malformed as there was some text outside the single quotes.

author: systimotic
description:
#### Pre-Submission Checklist
- [x] Your pull request targets the `staging` branch of freeCodeCamp.
- [x] Branch starts with either `fix/`, `feature/`, or `translate/` (e.g. `fix/signin-issue`)
- [x] You have only one commit (if not, [squash](http://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/how-to-squash-multiple-commits-into-one-with-git/13231) them into one commit).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass the command `npm test`. Use `git commit --amend` to amend any fixes.

#### Type of Change
<!-- What type of change does your code introduce? After creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
- [x] Small bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [ ] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

#### Description

1. The MailHog section was in the middle of the "Set Up freeCodeCamp" section. That made it difficult to skim over the section that was not relevant to your OS. I moved it out into its own section and added titles to it.
2. There were duplicate sections about naming and squashing commits. I kept the ones that were necessary in the step-by-step PR guide.
3. Most titles used Title Case, but not all of them did. I made them more consistent.
4. I added instructions for the `cp sample.env .env` command on Windows. With this change, I believe it's finally possible to follow this guide on Windows and end up with a working installation 🙌
5. I changed all instances of "FCC" to "freeCodeCamp". https://twitter.com/ossia/status/941412790325141506

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Important: If some of the following changes are not approved or if there's more to be done, please provide feedback so I can change them and apply the accepted changes when I work on converting the other sections to ES6.

ES6
* Change `var` to `let` or `const`
* Change callback functions to use arrow syntax

STYLE
* Change some single quotes to double quotes
  * Most challenges were using double quotes already while few had single quotes
  * Empty strings will keep their single quotes
* Add function call to solution
  * Some challenge solutions have the function call while some didn't. Now it is more consistent.
* Restyled solution code [See note 1]
  * Some challenges have comments but most solutions have them removed. They are now removed from all solutions to make them more consistent.
  * Some solutions didn't have new lines between blocks of code. This has been fixed.
  * Some solutions don't have spaces around operators `(i,i+1)` while most do `(i, i + 1)`. Now, they all do.
  * Some solutions didn't follow the style found [here](https://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/free-code-camp-javascript-style-guide/19121)
    * eg.  `if (num < 0) return '';` Had no curly brackets

NOTES
1. I'm not sure where the solution is displayed(if at all) but this makes them easier to read if they are.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Added ternary in /Panes/redux/index.js to set leftBound to dividerBuffer if leftPane.name === 'Map', otherwise, set to default behavior.

`leftBound` determines how far the panes can collapse to the left. When the Map pane is hidden, the next visible pane's `leftBound` property was adopting the hidden Map pane's `dividerLeft` property + the `dividerBuffer` property, which prevented the next visible pane from resizing properly.

author: BerkeleyTrue
description: As with many of my PR's, what should have been a simple feature instead evolved into a full on refactor as I found sections of code that where built extremely brittle. The main addition here is flash notifications in a full bleed style. We also have toasts messages. We should take care to distinguish between the two uses cases for these two very difference styles. We should use flash as we always have, sending messages between backend and the client app. Toasts should be notifications from the client app to the user. (There are also Modals, but don't get me started on those.) * updates webpack to latest * fetches flash messages on load * builds frameRunner through webpack (it is now possible to import modules directly there instead of passing things around through the document object) * fixes flash race condition * makes flash function standard with the rest of the world * factor settings toggle buttons into their own decoupled component * refactors settings page rendering logic * app now takes up full width/height of window without js logic

author: Bouncey
description:
The cliff notes on this PR:

- Consolidate the majority of  `updateMy***` actions into one `updateUserBackend` action
> Berkeley's third rule of Redux: "Never use two actions where one will do."
- Add more options to `/settings` to allow the user a more control over their public profile
- Consolidate all `verifyCert` endpoints into one `/certificate/verify` endpoint
- Consolidate all `showCert` endpoints into one `/c/:username/:cert`endoint
- Allow the user to complete projects via the challenge itself or the settings page, either of which updates `user.challengeMap` as well as `user.projects`.
- Allow the user to claim and see certs from `/settings`
- Allow the user to update their username from `/settings`, with verification from the backend that the username is available
- Fixes an issue where `lang` is `undefined` in the `mapService`
- Fixes an issue where the settings container wraps itself off screen in FireFox
- Fixes styling of flash messages

Their might be other things but I cannot remember right now.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Added several more tests and a working solution for this problem.

Here's the solution for QA:

```
function smallestMult(n){
  function gcd(a, b) {
    return b === 0 ? a : gcd(b, a%b); // Euclidean algorithm
  }
  
  function lcm(a, b) {
    return a * b / gcd(a, b);
  }
  var result = 1;
  for(var i = 2; i <= n; i++) {
    result = lcm(result, i);
  }
  return result;
}
```

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Added tests and working solution for Euler Problem 10.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's the solution for QA:

```
//noprotect
function primeSummation(n) {
  // Initialise an array containing only prime numbers
  let primes = [2];
  let result = 2;

  function isPrime(y, primes) {
    // Find sqrt(y)
    const sqrt = Math.floor(Math.sqrt(y));

    // Divide y by each applicable prime, return false if any of them divide y
    for (let i = 0; i < primes.length && primes[i] <= sqrt; i++) {
      if (y % primes[i] === 0) {
        return false;
      }
    }

    // At this point x must be prime
    return true;
  }

  // For every odd integer, add it to the array if it is prime
  for (let x = 3; x < n; x += 2) {
    if (isPrime(x, primes)) {
      if (x > n) {
        return result;
      } else {
        result += x;
        primes.push(x);
      }
    }
  }
  
  return result;
}
```

Tried to get a working solution without using `//noprotect` to override the loop protection, but was unable to. Maybe it's because the loop is too large, up to 2,000,000.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Noticed that problem 22 was missing from the seed file and decided to
add it along with some additional tests. However, I didn't include a
solution because I would have had to repeat the entire names array in
the solution string.

Here's a solution for QA:

```
function namesScores(arr) {
  const alphaNames = arr.sort();
  const alphabet = 'ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ';
  let totalScore = 0;
  
  alphaNames.forEach(function(name) {
    let currNameScore = 0;
    
    //split name and calc score for each letter
    const splitName = name.split('');
    splitName.forEach(function(letter) {
      currNameScore += alphabet.indexOf(letter) + 1;
    });
    
    // calc score based on name position in array
    totalScore += currNameScore * (alphaNames.indexOf(name) + 1);
  });
  
  return totalScore;
}
```

BREAKING CHANGE: None

- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #16395

#### Description
Removed flash message types provided by Express Flash and changed to types provided by Bootstrap.

I also wanted to note that I had an issue seeding the database for the first time. After running `npm run only-once`, the script failed at `node seed` and logged the following error:

```
/freeCodeCamp/seed/index.js:91
                  ...file,
                  ^^^

SyntaxError: Unexpected token ...
    at createScript (vm.js:56:10)
    at Object.runInThisContext (vm.js:97:10)
    at Module._compile (module.js:542:28)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
    at Module.runMain (module.js:604:10)
    at run (bootstrap_node.js:383:7)
    at startup (bootstrap_node.js:149:9)
```

I went ahead and removed that spread operator from `file` in `index.js` and was able to seed the database successfully and get the application running after that, but thought it was pretty strange that happened. I didn't commit my changes to `index.js` in this PR, but just wanted to call that out in case it's related to a separate issue.

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Added tests and a working solution for Project Euler problem 11. Also added some styling to the problem's description to highlight four numbers in red to be more in-line with the description on the projecteuler.net.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's a solution for QA:

```
function largestGridProduct(arr) {
  let maxProduct = 0;
  let currProduct = 0;
  
  function maxProductChecker(n) {
    if (n > maxProduct) {
      return maxProduct = n;
    }
  }
  
  // loop rows
  for (let r = 0; r < arr.length; r++) {
    // loop columns
    for (let c = 0; c < arr[r].length; c++) {
      const limit = arr[r].length - 3;
      
      // check horizontal
      if (c < limit) {
        currProduct = arr[r][c] * arr[r][c + 1] * arr[r][c + 2] * arr[r][c + 3];
        maxProductChecker(currProduct);
      }
      
      // check vertical
      if (r < limit) {
        currProduct = arr[r][c] * arr[r + 1][c] * arr[r + 2][c] * arr[r + 3][c];
        maxProductChecker(currProduct);
      }
      
      // check diagonal [\]
      if (c < limit && r < limit) {
        currProduct = arr[r][c] * arr[r + 1][c + 1] * arr[r + 2][c + 2] * arr[r + 3][c + 3];
        maxProductChecker(currProduct);
      }
      
      // check diagonal [/]
      if (c > 3 && r < limit) {
        currProduct = arr[r][c] * arr[r + 1][c - 1] * arr[r + 2][c - 2] * arr[r + 3][c - 3];
        maxProductChecker(currProduct);
      }
    }
  }
  
  return maxProduct;
}
```

Closes #16284
Refers #16319

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
What I did:
- Add logic to both of the `Editor.jsx` files to toggle `default/dracula` theme based on user's selected mode.
- Import theme's style into our style sheet.
- Add night mode style to the console output. (I use the exact same colors as the dracula's).
- Delete duplicate code in `Editor.less` as the code already exists in `challenges.less`.

Note:
This PR was **not** fully tested as syntax highlighting doesn't work on local version. The issue was addressed here: https://github.com/JedWatson/react-codemirror/issues/34.

author: alexch
description:
As part of #16519 -- 

`npm run unpack` extracts challenges into separate files for easier viewing and editing. The files are `.gitignore`d and will *not* be checked in, and all mongo seed importing will keep using the existing system; this is essentially a tool for editing `challenge.json` files. These HTML files are self-contained and run their own tests -- open a JS console to see the test results.

`npm run repack` gathers up the unpacked/edited HTML files into challenge-block JSON files.

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Cleaned up the description, added more tests, and a working solution.

Here's the solution:

```
//noprotect

function divisibleTriangleNumber(n) {
  
  let counter = 1;
  let triangleNumber = counter++;
  
  function getFactors(num) {
    let factors = [];
    
    let possibleFactor = 1;
    let sqrt = Math.sqrt(num);
    
    while (possibleFactor <= sqrt) {
      if (num % possibleFactor == 0) {
        factors.push(possibleFactor);

        var otherPossibleFactor = num / possibleFactor;
        if (otherPossibleFactor > possibleFactor) {
          factors.push(otherPossibleFactor);
        }
      }
      possibleFactor++;
    }

    return factors;
  }
  
  while (getFactors(triangleNumber).length < n) {
    triangleNumber += counter++;
  }
  console.log(triangleNumber);
  return triangleNumber;
}
```

BREAKING CHANGE: None

description:
This prevents methods that use the regular methods internally from
clashing

When a token is no longer valid (ttl has expired) validate() will attempt to `delete` before completing. This delete was overwritten to return an observable.

#### Description
An unclosed `<code>` tag in the React challenge "React: Use Array.filter() to Dynamically Filter an Array" was disrupting the DOM (`invariant` throws the error `Unable to find element with ID 646.`). As a result, the entire page broke. I closed this tag in the [seed file](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/seed/challenges/03-front-end-libraries/react.json) and have successfully tested the page locally.

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Renamed the default function, added arrays of number strings, and another test that uses the smaller array.

Here is a working solution for QA:

```
function largeSum(arr) {
  
  let sum = 0;
  
  arr.forEach(function(num) {
    sum += parseInt(num, 10);
  });
  
  sum = sum.toString(10);
  
  sum = sum.substr(0, 1) + sum.substr(2);
  
  let firstTen = sum.slice(0, 10);

  return parseInt(firstTen, 10);
}
```

BREAKING CHANGE: None

#### Description

Added more tests, a solution, and an image to make the description more clear. 

The image is from Project Euler but is re-hosted on imgur. Should be fine to use the image under the Creative Commons Licence, but if not, I could recreate it and update this PR.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's the solution for QA:

```
function latticePaths(gridSize) {
  let paths = 1;
  
  for (let i = 0; i < gridSize; i++) {
    paths *= (2 * gridSize) - i;
    paths /= i + 1;
  }
  return paths;
}
```

description:

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #16636

#### The Problem
Enzyme tests were feeding numbers into the value of an `input`. However, according to the MDN web docs for [HTMLInputElement](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLInputElement), the `value` attribute of the Input Element in HTML is always of type String. Even the type attribute only alters the "type of control to display"—the value of an input with `type="number"` is still stored as a string. 

The challenge, on ternary operators, necessitates checking if an input value (`this.state.userAge`) is empty. As a consequence:
```js
// the tests will green-light this boolean expression; numbers !== strings
this.state.userAge !== "" ? ... 

// this boolean expression does not work; unlike strings, numbers have no length attribute
this.state.userAge > 0 ? ...
```

#### My Solution

I've changed the input values three tests were feeding the challenge from numbers to strings. That way, users can use both of these booleans to test the non-emptiness of the input:
```
1) inputText !== "";
2) inputText.length > 0;

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Edited the description so the exponents are displayed properly, and
added more tests and a solution.

Here's the solution for QA:

```
function powerDigitSum(exponent) {
  const bigNum = [1];
  let sum = 0;
  
  for (let i = 1; i <= exponent; i++) {
    let count = bigNum.length + 1;
    let overflow = 0;
    for (let j = 0; j < count; j++) {
      let digit = bigNum[j] || 0;
      digit = 2 * digit + overflow;
      
      if (digit > 9) {
        digit -= 10;
        overflow = 1;
      } else {
        overflow = 0;
      }
      
      bigNum[j] = digit;
    }
  }
  
  bigNum.forEach(function(num) {
    return sum += num;
  });
  
  return sum;
}
```

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Closes #16643 

#### Description

In the ES6 challenges, there is "use strict" included in the code. However, there is no explanation of its meaning or what it does anywhere. This PR hopes to provide a better learning experience for the user in this respect.

It differs from #16650, which addresses the same issue, in the following ways:
- **It provides an example.** Most JavaScript beginners do not understand what the "unsafe actions" in #16650 are; I provide a two-line code example (long enough to let the user understand, but short enough to not clutter the page with directions).
- **It is more sensibly worded.** The explanation in #16650 is not only a run-on sentence, but it also exhibits a misunderstanding of Strict Mode (inferred from incorrect usage of capitalization, quotes, and syntax).
- **The description location is correct.** My explanation is grouped with the introductory description of the challenge, unlike #16650's, which is grouped in the challenge instructions section.
- _The branch name is correct 😜_ ([contributing guidelines](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/staging/CONTRIBUTING.md))

- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #16645 

#### Description

There was an error in one of the tests for [this Applied Accessibility challenge](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/applied-accessibility/improve-accessibility-of-audio-content-with-the-audio-element). The test failed to detect a closed audio tag and threw an error (`cannot read property 'length' of null`) in the console.

Faulty regex: `/<audio id=\"meowClip\" controls>/g`. The addition of the "meowClip" id attribute in the audio tag test was never specified in the directions and seems to have mistaken the challenge description (which uses a `<audio id="meowClip">` tag as an example) for a solution. 

Since the faulty regex would never match anything and the test used a `.match(...).length` to check if the number of closing tags matched the number of opening tags, it threw the aforementioned error `cannot read property 'length' of null`. 

I've replaced the regex to simply be `/<audio>/g` and added an extra boolean to prevent the null-case.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Changed the description to more closely match the one on the Project
Euler page. Also added another test and solution.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's a solution for QA:

```
function maximumPathSumI(triangle) {
  let maxSum = triangle.slice();
  
  for (let i = triangle.length - 1; i > 0; i--) {
    let currentRow = maxSum[i];
    let previousRow = maxSum[i - 1];
    const temp = [];
    for (let j = 0; j < i; j++) {
      temp.push(Math.max((currentRow[j] + previousRow[j]), (currentRow[j + 1] + previousRow[j])));
    }
    maxSum[i - 1] = temp;
    maxSum.pop();
  }

  return maxSum[0][0];
}
```

Added additional tests and a working solution for this problem.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's my solution for QA:

```
function countingSundays(firstYear, lastYear) {
  let sundays = 0;
  
  for (let year = firstYear; year <= lastYear; year++) {
    for (let month = 1; month <= 12; month++) {
      const thisDate = new Date(year, month, 1);
      if (thisDate.getDay() === 0) {
        sundays++;
      }
    }
  }
  
  return sundays;
}
```

#### Description

From personal experience and the creators of #16660 and #16707, the users are putting a direct Glitch URL (`https://glitch.com/edit/#!/crimson-swim`) into the solution input, when they should instead be giving the front-facing URL (`https://crimson-swim.glitch.me`)

This PR includes a few changes to help the user differentiate these two types of Glitch URLs.

If need be, I'd be glad to add more instructions in text or add more `SolutionInput` component tests.

- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [x] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #16710 

#### Description

The tests in [React: Learn About Self-Closing JSX Tags](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/react/learn-about-selfclosing-jsx-tags) required the learner to add this line to the end of their code:
```js
ReactDOM.render(JSX, document.getElementById('challenge-node'));
```

However, this would render the component twice was due to the tail code. The tail in the seed contained a `ReactDOM.render` line, thus resulting in two renders. 

My solution was to just remove the test and modify the solution to match that deletion. Currently, it is inconsistent with the behaviors of all of the other React DOM element challenges. For example, in the challenge before, [Define an HTML Class in JSX](https://beta.freecodecamp.org/en/challenges/react/define-an-html-class-in-jsx), no `ReactDOM.render` is needed to pass the challenge.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
In order to fix a small bug with two scrollbars appearing in a challenge preview pane, I've hidden the scrollbar in the div surrounding the challenge preview iframe. 

![sorta-fixed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20032554/36345728-5e120a0c-13fe-11e8-938e-cb6dc00e158a.jpg)

However, there is still some whitespace surrounding the preview pane due to the styling of the parent Pane component. To remove the odd whitespace, I removed the padding from the left and right sides.
 
![fixed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20032554/36345733-8b5333ce-13fe-11e8-863b-c577cdb17d84.jpg)

- [x] Tested changes locally.

Closes #16741

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Called updateSuccessMessage passing it a random compliment after running the tests in order to show a different quote each time the users see the CompletionModal. 

Note: Currently updateSuccessMessage is called every time the user run the tests. Any insight on how or where to call it only when all the tests are passed in order to improve performance would be great.

I know the logic to display the modal when all the test are passed but it's inside of the updateTests reducer
```js
tests.length > 0 && tests.every(test => test.pass && !test.err)
```

author: Bouncey
description:
Currently on beta, we have high response times for a react page. This PR makes an attempt to address this.

The test environment was my local machine with one instance of `mongo` and four instances of the production app with 1 CPU and 1GB each. The testing lib was `artillery`

Each test consisted of 50 virtual users issuing 20 requests each to
`http://localhost:3000/en/challenges/basic-html-and-html5/learn-how-freecodecamp-works`

`RPS sent` is the number of requests per second
`min`, `max`, `median`, `p95` and `p99` are response times in ms.

## Staging
```sh
All virtual users finished
Summary report @ 12:16:11(+0000) 2018-02-28
  Scenarios launched:  50
  Scenarios completed: 50
  Requests completed:  1000
  RPS sent: 13.97
  Request latency:
    min: 375.8
    max: 5948.5
    median: 2540.4
    p95: 3393.8
    p99: 3972.8
  Scenario counts:
    0: 50 (100%)
  Codes:
    200: 1000
```

## Caching markup by route

### `req.originalUrl in markupMap`
```sh
All virtual users finished
Summary report @ 13:28:31(+0000) 2018-02-28
  Scenarios launched:  50
  Scenarios completed: 50
  Requests completed:  1000
  RPS sent: 53.85
  Request latency:
    min: 86.6
    max: 2596.6
    median: 543.8
    p95: 1304.5
    p99: 2211.3
  Scenario counts:
    0: 50 (100%)
  Codes:
    200: 1000
```

### `markupMap.hasOwnProperty(req.originalUrl)`
```sh
All virtual users finished
Summary report @ 13:31:29(+0000) 2018-02-28
  Scenarios launched:  50
  Scenarios completed: 50
  Requests completed:  1000
  RPS sent: 53.82
  Request latency:
    min: 81.4
    max: 2358.5
    median: 579.9
    p95: 1261.7
    p99: 2006.3
  Scenario counts:
    0: 50 (100%)
  Codes:
    200: 1000
```

## Comparisons

Method | RPS | Median Response | Reduction (response time)
-----------|------|------------------------|-----
Current | 13.97 | 2540.4 | N/A
route in cache | 53.85 | 543.8 | 78.6%
cache has route | 53.82 | 579.9 | 77.2%

I am open to suggestions and ideas as to how to reduce the response time further

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Provide feedback to the user that the app is 'doing stuff' whilst we wait for a response from the server for the requested block.

This PR adds an overlay loader which is triggered when we do not have the current challenge description.

This PR also addresses my mistake in thinking that `lodash.merge()` wasn't mutating state.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
Added user stories to Applied Responsive Web Design Projects, Front End Libraries Projects, and Data Visualization Projects.
The user stories were copied from the unit test, with some minor modifications such as adding punctuation, correcting small typos, and replacing quotation marks with the `<code>` tag to highlight keywords (element name, id name, class name, etc.).
I also numbered the user stories to make it easier to keep track.
The number of user stories is less than the number of test cases by 1 because I did not include the 'Technology Stack' test. I, instead, just placed it on top of the user story list as it looks more like a note than a user story to me.

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->
File: es6.json

1. Challenge Title: "Use the Rest Operator with Function Parameters"
  Typo "so that is uses the..."  fixed to "so that it uses the..."

2. Challenge Title: "Write Concise Object Literal Declarations Using Simple Fields"
  Typo: "for easily definining object" fixed to "for easily defining object"

3. Challenge Title: "Use getters and setters to Control Access to an Object"
  Typo1: "accepts Farenheit temperature"  fixed to "accepts Fahrenheit temperature"

  Typo2: "const thermos = new Thermostat(76); // setting in Farenheit scale"  
             fixed to "const thermos = new Thermostat(76); // setting in Fahrenheit scale"

By Paul (@PolarisTLX) and Kyle (@jklemon17)

- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds new functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would change existing functionality)
- [ ] Add new translation (feature adding new translations)

#### Checklist:
<!-- Go over all points below, and after creating the PR, tick the checkboxes that apply. -->
<!-- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask in the Contributors room linked above. We're here to help! -->
- [x] Tested changes locally.
- [ ] Addressed currently open issue (replace XXXXX with an issue no in next line)

Closes #XXXXX

#### Description
<!-- Describe your changes in detail -->

Ported the solution for Project Euler 32 user @elliotjz contributed to
the fCC Arcade Mode.

BREAKING CHANGE: None

Here's the solution for QA:

```
function pandigitalProducts() {
  function is1to9Pandigital(...numbers) {
    const digitStr = concatenateNums(...numbers);

    // check if length is 9
    if (digitStr.length !== 9) {
      return false;
    }

    // check if pandigital
    for (let i = digitStr.length; i > 0; i--) {
      if (digitStr.indexOf(i.toString()) === -1) {
        return false;
      }
    }
    return true;
  }

  function concatenateNums(...numbers) {
    let digitStr = '';
    for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
      digitStr += numbers[i].toString();
    }
    return digitStr;
  }

  const pandigitalNums = [];
  let sum = 0;
  // limit mult 1 to 9876. Anything more than this will
  // result in a product with more than 4 digits, which means
  // the equation will have more than 9 digits
  for (let mult1 = 2; mult1 < 9876; mult1++) {
    // start mult 2 at 123. Anything lower than this will
    // create a equation with less than 9 digits
    let mult2 = 123;
    while (concatenateNums(mult1, mult2, mult1 * mult2).length < 10) {
      if (is1to9Pandigital(mult1, mult2, mult1 * mult2)
          && !pandigitalNums.includes(mult1 * mult2)) {
        pandigitalNums.push(mult1 * mult2);
        sum += mult1 * mult2;
      }
      mult2++;
    }
  }
  return sum;
}
```
